awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Controlled source seismic investigation of the top of the Yellowstone magmatic system
awd_abstract_narration:
Among the most important mysteries regarding the Yellowstone volcanic system is whether it currently contains upper crustal magma with high enough melt fractions to be eruptible over human time scales. Prior imaging of the structure beneath Yellowstone caldera offers potentially conflicting evidence with some studies indicating magma that is unlikely to be eruptible and others indicating magma that is near the eruptible range but only present in isolated locations. These studies relied on relatively long wavelength sampling from natural seismic sources such as earthquakes. This project will use a controlled seismic source, a high-frequency vibrator truck, and hundreds of densely spaced seismic instruments to scrutinize the top of the Yellowstone magma reservoir, estimated to be  about 4-8 km below the surface. This experiment will provide a new level on constraint on the melts at the top of the magma reservoir. Additionally, the project will gain insights on the distribution of hydrothermal fluids above the magma reservoir including their depth extent and the degree of subsurface connectivity among distinct geothermal basins at the surface. This project increases the involvement of younger generations of scientists in controlled source research projects, providing training in methods that are relevant to natural resource exploration industries. Two graduate students will be trained in applied seismic imaging. The investigators will engage with National Park personnel to advance informal education for Yellowstone’s  approximately 4 million annual visitors.

The project primarily seeks to test whether seismic velocities near the top of the Yellowstone magma reservoir are consistent with concentrations of magma approaching eruptible melt fractions. Additionally, it will investigate reservoirs and pathways for magmatic volatiles that influence upper crustal seismicity and the locations of distinct geothermal basins within the caldera. A new ability to address these questions will be provided by controlled source data collection with an array of 3-component receivers along two densely sampled transects whose locations are guided by prior passive source imaging studies. Controlled source reflection imaging and amplitude versus offset analysis are rarely possible above silicic magma reservoirs, because most are too small or lack road access directly above the reservoirs. In this case, favorable road transects exist above the magma reservoir inferred from passive source imaging with sparser arrays and lower frequencies. Prior estimates of melt fractions in the upper crustal reservoir vary widely, and the new survey will help clarify the potential presence and volume of eruptible magma using reflected wave amplitudes from controlled source P-to-P and P-to-S reflections. The combination of Vp and Vs constraints also has the potential to map subsurface accumulations of magmatic volatiles, which may provide new insights into the physical properties of the source regions of seismicity and deep underpinnings of distinct geothermal basins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Magma reservoirs are important to understand because they fuel hazardous volcanoes and over long (geologic) time scales they create new crust and concentrate economic deposits of metal ores. Modern magma reservoirs are hidden beneath the surface and approaches like geophysical surveys with seismic waves are one of the main ways to identify and characterize them. Many years of seismic studies using naturally-occurring signals have provided strong evidence of a magma reservoir roughly in the upper crust beneath Yellowstone caldera, but estimates of the depth to the top of the reservoir and state of fluids at the top of the reservoir vary widely. This research project collected new data with an array of hundreds of seismometers and a controlled seismic source from a heavy truck-mounted vibration system that sends a known signal into the subsurface without damaging the environment. The new data provide observations of seismic wave reflections from the top of the magma reservoir. The reflected waves indicate that it is a very sharp boundary with an abrupt increase in the fraction of fluid present over a depth increase of only about 100 meters. The top of the magma reservoir is about 4.5-5 kilometers deep beneath the southwestern part of the caldera and about 3.5-4 kilometers deep beneath the northeastern part of the caldera, and the latter is where prior studies suggest magma is most concentrated. The shallow depths of the top of the magma reservoir indicate conditions where substantial amounts of fluids like water and carbon dioxide are expected to separate from the magma forming bubbles. Some bubbles escape to the surface and contribute to observed gas emissions in the caldera. The ratio of amplitudes of reflected seismic P-waves and P-to-S waves in the new data provide evidence that a fraction of the bubbles may also be accumulating near the top of the magma reservoir. The existence of a sharp top to the reservoir at well-defined depths and potential evidence of bubble accumulation are valuable new contributions to understanding the state of the magmatic system.

 

The seismic research described above was primarily conducted by two graduate students at the University of New Mexico who received training in seismic imaging techniques and more general professional skills in computational processing of large volumes of time series data, along with training in written and oral communication of technical science. The students and the principal investigator used project resources for case studies in classes at the University of New Mexico and for outreach activities to teach middle and high school students in Albuquerque about career opportunities in the geosciences. As finalized graphics become available the project results will be communicated with Yellowstone National Park staff to improve informal education resources for the public.


Last Modified: 11/09/2023
Modified by: Brandon Schmandt
